reviews.review_msg: Class gave good insights and knowledge in a way that was digestible even for people that aren't ARCH majors. The grade was only based on written work, and none of it felt like it was too time consuming or marked unfairly. Definitely worth picking this one if you're looking to fulfill lower div requirements for GES.

Lectures were very monotone and dry audio files with PowerPoint slides that are almost entirely text. Explains things well enough if you can pay attention. Graded by papers only, no tests. Papers are explained well and he isn't a tough marker.

Prof. Welch is very passionate about this field, a likeable person, and a more than fair marker. But the class felt very disorganized, and the readings were extremely hard to learn from. Very easy class, but a lot of work if you're taking it during summer session. Groupwork is free marks, but sucks if you get stuck with a lazy group member.
I still don't know what I actually learnt in this class this made no sense
Replace him with a new professor who actually knows how to write assignment instructions clearly and knows how to deal with modern technologies

My biggest issue with this class is the number of tech issues that Prof. Welch and the TA struggled with (modules/quizzes not being uploaded). The majority of the class focuses on US CHM policy, which does not make sense, as many students who have to take this course will likely work in Canada. Group work every class, even though it's online.

This prof needs to take a tech course. There were many technical errors on canvas regarding posting material and breakout rooms which was very inconvenient, and “lectures” were all readings. group assignments often made little sense or didn't have much meaning as the steps were so strict. not an enjoyable course and heavy homework every week.

Welch told us that bad reviews come from being a good prof... twisted logic there. I'm a motivated student and this class made me hate school. Assignments are unclear, boring, and marked on if you can fit a table into a page limit (what??). Weekly quiz, group work, AND assignment. His unpublished textbook is terribly written. Avoid this class!

He is very caring when you actively participate in his class/lectures with questions & concerns * wants you to have a good learning outcome, but assignments can be confusing, & isn't super tech. savvy resulting in many missing quizzes & modules that weren't updated until a day before they were due. probably wouldn't take his online course again.

This class was awful. There were no clear guidelines, and expected you to participate and know everything about archaeology. He very obviously liked the archaeology major students and gave them special treatment. Participation and group assignments were a large part of your grade. Do not take with John. Save yourself the headache.

Although people will likely feel confused when taking this course, I can say this guy is the best prof I ever had. He is passionate and puts a lot of effort into this course, he loves student participation and he makes sure you understand something when you ask him questions. This course will be confusing but you will not regret taking it. 5/5

So far, the worst professor I had while studying in Canada. The explanations are extremely unclear, even we he was asked to clarify his requirements for assignments 3 times in a row by various people. Very emotional, no practical approach to study.I am deeply disappointed.

Loves student participation. Course material is fairly boring but John is a knowledgable, funny, interesting prof who connects material to other things in new ways.  easy but weird group assignments. Difficult quizzes based on useless book but John does his best to make student stupidity or laziness look good by marking dumb answers right. Good guy
